section-block.rac_book_summary: Have you ever wondered why it rains? Or what makes the wind? Weather affects us every day, so understanding why it’s rainy, snowy, sunny, or windy is a good idea.

Let’s peek out our window to check the weather. What do we see?
I see the letter n in the word need. Who can come point to the n in need?
I see the letter m in the word make. Who can come point to the m in make?
What do you see on this page? Raise your hand if you like to swim in the summer.
After a storm, sometimes there’s a rainbow. What colors do we see in a rainbow?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What kind of weather did you learn about?

Why is it a good idea to check the weather?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children’s vocabulary is influenced not only by the quantity of words they hear but by the quality of words. By three to four years of age, children are ready to be exposed to more challenging words. For example, saying humongous instead of big or peek instead of look can positively contribute to children’s vocabulary development.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Be Curious
section-block.rac_body-text: Start a discussion by asking: Who knows what it means to be curious? Acknowledge suggestions from children. When I see, hear, or read something that is new to me, I might ask, “What is that?” or “Why did that happen?” By asking questions like these, I can learn new things and find answers. What are you curious about?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to use our curiosity as we revisit the big book Weather, written by Kristin Baird Rattini.
Clifford loves to be curious! When he learns about something, he likes to ask, “Why?” Let’s see where our curiosity takes us as we read about weather!

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
Read aloud the book and the Day 2 prompts.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This section is called “What Is Weather?” Do you know what this mark is called? A question mark tells readers that this is a question. Who can find and point to another question mark?
What did you read on this page that makes you curious? What questions do you have about it? (MB)
This section is called “What Comes from Clouds?” I’m curious about the answer. How can I ask questions to find the answer? (MB)
Thunderstorm is a special kind of word called a compound word. What two words do you hear in the word thunderstorm?
Weather can be wild! What are you curious about on these pages? (MB)
This boy has an umbrella. Can you explain why he has an umbrella?

section.rac_body-text: Challenge children to be curious as you play Weather-Word Picture Clues. Explain that you will think of a weather-related word that is also a compound word. Tell children that you will quickly draw each part of the weather word. They will guess the two picture words and put them together. Weather-related compound words can include sunglasses, snowball, sunlight, raincoat, and rainbow.
Transcribe children’s speech as they share which type of weather makes them curious.
Do the writing on a computer. Then print out copies for children to share.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Novelty sparks curiosity in the young child. To encourage curiosity, model being curious, ask questions, answer children’s questions, be spontaneous, and encourage observation. (Miller/Scholastic.com)

section-block.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Say: All people, animals, and plants need the light and heat from the sun. All living things also need water. How does weather help us get these things?

section-block.rac_body-text: Red and orange / green and blue / Shiny yellow, purple too. / All the colors that we know, / we see in the rainbow!

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book Weather by Kristin Baird Rattini.
Pablo loves learning facts about weather!
This is the Guiding Question I want you to think about as we read the book Weather:
How does weather help us?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the big book and the Day 3 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: These pages are about the sun. How does the sun help us?
These pages are about clouds. Water droplets float through the air to make clouds. What else can float through the air?

We read about three kinds of clouds. Let’s clap out each syllable in the word cumulus. What do cumulus clouds look like? Let’s clap out each syllable in stratus. What do stratus clouds look like? Let’s clap out each syllable in cirrus. What do cirrus clouds look like?
Raise your hand if you like rain. Why do we need rain? What happens if we don’t get enough rain?
What two words do you hear in the word rainbow? Who remembers what this kind of word is called?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Sunlight is a compound word, too. What two words do you hear in sunlight?
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What’s your favorite kind of weather?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
How does weather help us?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Then, use Equity Sticks to choose two or three children to respond.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Wind moves the clouds. It makes a cool breeze.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to talk and write about the weather. Discuss correct directionality when writing together.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does the sun keep us warm?
How can rain, wind, and snow be dangerous?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: While doing multiple readings of the same book over the course of several days is useful to all children, it’s especially beneficial to multilingual preschoolers. At this age, children are working to make sense of their native language on top of a new language. Repetition is crucial.

section-block.rac_body-text: Lead a discussion about what children have learned about different kinds of weather. Ask:What do you do to get ready for different kinds of weather?

Show the Big Chart. Let’s look at the picture of the two children in the sand. There’s only one pail. If you were one of the children in this picture, what might you say if you wanted to use the pail? How do you think the two children are sharing the pail and cup? (MB)

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read “What’s the Weather?” What will he words and pictures tell us?
Pablo loves to learn about different weather! “What’s the Weather?” is an informational poster about weather. Let’s read!
Weather and “What’s the Weather?” both tell us about weather. Let’s see what’s the same about these two texts!
As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to the concept question:

section.rac_body-text: Share the poster with children. Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart. Then, use these prompts to read and discuss the poster. Use the Equity Sticks to choose children to take turns responding.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Each picture has a word next to it. These are called labels. What do you think the label next to the child with the umbrella says?
Who can point to the label for the picture of the child in the snow? Read the word with me: Snowy.
Look at the child flying a kite. What makes the kite fly? Have you ever flown a kite on a windy day?
What are these children doing? Look at the sky. What kind of weather do you see? Do you think that the children are warm or cold? Why?

section.rac_body-text: Tell children that they will create a thunderstorm in the classroom! Explain that they must keep quiet so they can hear the storm coming and then going away. Say: It’s starting to drizzle. Copy my movements. Rub your fingers together. It’s drizzling harder now. Rub palms together. It’s a downpour! Pat knees. Here comes the thunder! Stomp feet. Perform the movements in reverse for the storm to pass.
Provide a writing prompt about the weather. Guide children and assist with their writing as needed.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Without knowing it, children are identifying the connection between one event and another when learning about weather. For example, “Because it’s raining, I carry an umbrella.” Look for daily opportunities to help children identify cause and effect relationships.

section-block.rac_body-text: Tell children that you want to celebrate the weather!

Look at the sun, shining bright! (hold up right hand) / Here come the clouds, dark as night. (hold up left hand) / Rain starts to fall, hitting the ground. (wiggle fingers) / Now it’s raining all over town. / When the clouds slowly pass on by, / a beautiful rainbow fills the sky! (make an arc over head with both arms)

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and act out the Big Book Weather by Kristin Baird Rattini.
Pablo loves this book because it’s an informational text about weather. Informational texts tell us about things that are real.
This week, we read about different kinds of weather and what can cause them. As we read the book one more time, I want you to think about this Guiding Question:
How can you plan for the weather?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s pretend to jump into a pool on a hot day? Ready? Jump!
What do we say if we have more than one cloud? Can we make the word cloud mean more than one? What about wind? What about rain? What about snow?
page 17
Let’s pretend to jump in rain puddles! Splash!
Let’s pretend it’s raining. Now let’s pretend it’s cold enough for the rain to freeze. Look, it’s snowing! What can you wear so your hands don’t freeze?
Let’s pretend it’s a windy day and we’re flying a kite. Is the wind making your kite dance?
How can you plan for each kind of weather? What would you wear or bring with you when you go outside?

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to Turn and Talk about the Guiding Question:
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How can you plan for the weather?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Then, use the Equity Sticks to choose two or three children to share their answers.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: I can wear sunscreen if it’s sunny.
I can stay inside if it’s stormy.
I can use an umbrella if it’s raining.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write details about one type of weather they learned about this week. Allow them to share their work with classmates.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Can you use an umbrella if it’s raining?
I can use an um______ (umbrella) if it’s raining.
I can use an umbrella if it’s raining.
How can knowing the weather keep you safe?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children are natural storytellers. Reenacting what they’ve read helps to build developing literacy skills. Although the Big Book Weather is a nonfiction selection, acting out what it’s like to experience different kinds of weather and weather-related activities helps children make personal connections to the information. And it’s fun!
